articles.headline: Roundup Maker to Pay $10 Billion to Settle Cancer Suits
articles.snippet: Bayer faced tens of thousands of claims linking the weedkiller to cases of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Some of the money is set aside for future cases.
articles.abstract: Bayer faced tens of thousands of claims linking the weedkiller to cases of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Some of the money is set aside for future cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Bayer, the giant German chemical and pharmaceutical maker, acquired Monsanto two years ago, the company knew it was also buying the world’s best-known weedkiller. What it didn’t anticipate was a legal firestorm over claims that the herbicide, Roundup, caused cancer.

articles.headline: In Reversal, Trump-Comey Mini-Series Will Now Air Before Election Day
articles.snippet: The series director criticized ViacomCBS’s announcement that it would broadcast “The Comey Rule” in late November. On Wednesday, the air date was moved to September.
articles.abstract: The series director criticized ViacomCBS’s announcement that it would broadcast “The Comey Rule” in late November. On Wednesday, the air date was moved to September.

articles.headline: As Sales Rise, Automakers Ramp Up Production
articles.snippet: Demand has been stronger than expected since states began reopening, but some experts worry about the effect of a new surge in coronavirus cases.
articles.abstract: Demand has been stronger than expected since states began reopening, but some experts worry about the effect of a new surge in coronavirus cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just two months ago, the auto industry was bracing for disaster. As the coronavirus spread, automakers shut down plants, and car sales plunged.

articles.headline: A Winner on Election Day in November? Don’t Count on It
articles.snippet: The lack of race results in New York and Kentucky this week is a prelude for the presidential election, as officials strain to deal with a deluge of absentee ballots and a jumble of voting deadlines.
articles.abstract: The lack of race results in New York and Kentucky this week is a prelude for the presidential election, as officials strain to deal with a deluge of absentee ballots and a jumble of voting deadlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cliffhanger elections on Tuesday night in Kentucky and New York didn’t just leave the candidates and voters in a state of suspended animation wondering who had won. Election officials, lawyers and political strategists in both parties said the lack of results was a bracing preview of what could come after the polls close in November: No clear and immediate winner in the presidential race.

articles.headline: Coronavirus Surge Raises Alarm as States Report New Highs
articles.snippet: Florida, Texas, Oklahoma and South Carolina set daily records. Nationwide, more than 36,000 cases were reported Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Florida, Texas, Oklahoma and South Carolina set daily records. Nationwide, more than 36,000 cases were reported Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, governors, mayors, investors and others across the United States woke up to news that was impossible to ignore. More than 35,000 new coronavirus cases had been identified the day before. It was the highest number reported in a single day since late April.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Anupreeta Das

articles.headline: Barr’s Interest in Google Antitrust Case Keeps It Moving Swiftly
articles.snippet: Attorney General William Barr’s attention to the Justice Department investigation shows the high stakes for the agency and for him.
articles.abstract: Attorney General William Barr’s attention to the Justice Department investigation shows the high stakes for the agency and for him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, lawyers at the Justice Department have been marshaling their forces for a possible antitrust lawsuit against Google, spurred on by the personal interest of Attorney General William P. Barr.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Bail Funds, Flush With Cash, Learn to ‘Grind Through This Horrible Process’
articles.snippet: Donors have given more than $90 million to help buy the freedom of those awaiting trial behind bars.
articles.abstract: Donors have given more than $90 million to help buy the freedom of those awaiting trial behind bars.
articles.lead_paragraph: One afternoon in June, Elisabeth Epps hopped into her partner’s Jeep and rode from Denver to Boulder, carrying cashier’s checks worth nearly $16,000.

articles.headline: With Unemployment Offices Busy, Recovery Seems a ‘Long Haul’
articles.snippet: As coronavirus hot spots flare across the U.S., adding to economic worries, new jobless claims surpassed one million for the 14th week.
articles.abstract: As coronavirus hot spots flare across the U.S., adding to economic worries, new jobless claims surpassed one million for the 14th week.
articles.lead_paragraph: As American businesses reopen in fits and starts — and anxiety over new coronavirus hot spots increases — state unemployment offices still have their hands full.
